Under the ALP's proposal, businesses would only have to keep records to justify their turnover. If audited, they would not have to justify their input tax credit claims or details of their sales. This again would increase the possibility of abuse, which is not something that this side of the House accepts as being good policy. Businesses previously in a refund situation would be allowed to apply previous ratios even though they may no longer be in a refund situation. This is ludicrous, and I am sure it is something that, in government, the opposition would have to overturn-and to what ramifications for small business? Businesses may also nominate an industry that is known to have a more favourable ratio. All of these things undermine people's trust and faith in a just taxation system. What the government has proposed here and what I am sure will pass both in here and in the Senate are measures which will simplify the taxation system and will ensure that small business people have more time to spend on their businesses, generating profits and jobs, which is good for Australia. The Howard government and Minister Hockey in particular, who represents small business very ably, very professionally and with great dedication, will ensure that the interests of small business are always uppermost in the minds of the coalition government. I commend the bill to the House. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: INDIRECT TAX LEGISLATION
text: by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA Rearrangement

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: BUSINESS
text: Menzies-Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (8.43 p.m.)-by leave-I move: That consideration of government business order of the day Nos 3 to 8 be postponed until a later hour this day. Question agreed to. SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE (LEARNING TOGETHER-ACHIEVEMENT NA OPPORTUNITY) BILL 2004 Cognate bill: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND NA ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2004 Second Reading Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Dr Nelson: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I seek leave to move the second reading amendment being circulated in my name. The government has delayed the introduction of the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 into this parliament, unfortunately leaving schools in a very uncertain funding position. Leaving debate on this bill until August, just four months before the end of the school year, means that schools, principals, students, teachers and parents are all in an uncertain and precarious position. Of course, we on this side of the House do know how schools work. We know that this is about the time when schools are making their decisions for 2005-students are choosing their subjects; principals are making decisions about staff-and they have to know what their funding will be for next year in order to make those decisions. Clearly the government really does not care about the havoc that funding uncertainty can cause for schools. It is blatantly irresponsible of the government to introduce this bill so late in the year. The delay is yet another case of this government playing politics with children's education. By contrast, Labor have outlined the principles on which schools should be funded, and these are in stark contrast to the government's unfair funding system. Labor stand by our commitment to needs based funding for all schools. We will increase funding to government schools and redistribute funding away from high-fee non-government schools to more needy Catholic and lower fee independent schools. The non-government sector as a whole will not lose any funding. We will fight the government's unfair funding system at the coming election. For me, this will be a very important fight-a critical fight-to get fairness back into schools funding. It is a fight that we certainly will not resile from. But Labor's determination to change the government's divisive funding system will not put at risk funding certainty for our schools now. As I said, the government should be condemned for holding back on this bill until so late in the year. As you may know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the funding contained in this bill was actually announced back in March. It has taken months for the parliament to see the bill and even longer for it to come on for debate. Labor will allow this bill to pass for one reason only-that is, to give schools and parents the certainty that they need for next year. Unlike the government, we will not play politics with children's education. But, on winning the election, Labor will introduce fairer, needs based funding legislation that will begin in 2006, and our first budget will contain additional funding for government schools. Labor's education policy will have many elements, and will include establishing a national schools resource standard to make sure that all schools in Australia, whether they government, Catholic or independent, have the resources to deliver a high standard of education. We want to fund all schools on the basis of need. We have negotiated a national schools agreement with state and territory governments and we will negotiate agreements with other non-government school authorities to deliver needs based funding. For Labor, at both a national and a state and territory level, significantly increasing the funding for government schools will be one of the priorities that this nation can be proud of. Ensuring a basic level of funding for all non-government schools and guaranteeing the overall funding level for the nongovernment sector-these are commitments that Labor have made. But we do intend to redistribute funding away from high-fee, wealthy schools to lower fee, needy Catholic and independent schools. We want to provide incentives to make sure that the best teachers, the most experienced teachers, and school leaders are available to assist schools with concentrations of students with special needs. We have announced that we intend to pay the TAFE fees for secondary school students. We will employ 1,080 training mentors to make sure that young people are helped to stay on at school or to move into full-time jobs or further training. We will provide extra resources to improve school discipline. We will have a national action plan to get more male teachers into schools, and we will recruit more fathers and other men-whether they are grandads, uncles or other leaders in our community-to serve as role models in our schools. We have announced a Bright Futures program to support secondary school students from disadvantaged backgrounds to progress to university or TAFE. The bill that we are debating here tonight will operate for only one year, 2005, if Labor are win the upcoming election. We are supporting funding for 2005 as a transition year prior to the adoption of Labor's fairer, needs based funding policy. Labor do not support the government's unfair and divisive schools funding system, which has seen the largest funding increases go to the wealthiest schools in this country. Take the King's School in Parramatta in Sydney, for example. They received a 165 per cent increase in funding between 2001 and 2004 from this Howard government. By contrast, a couple of schools just around the corner from the King's School in Parramatta, Fairvale High School and Trinity Catholic College, have had to make do with a 20 per cent and a 25 per cent adjustment respectively-barely enough to cover annual increases. Trinity Catholic College does not have anything like the facilities of King's. It College and Fairvale High-which certainly does not have the facilities of King's-that are in desperate need of more resources. Labor believe-so differently from the Howard government-that every Australian child is entitled to a great standard of education. That means for us that every child at every school will get a basic level of funding for their education. But we believe that priority in funding above that basic level must be given to schools on the basis of educational and financial need. I do not know how many people recognise that this is what has happened under the Howard government but I hope that every member of this parliament will stop for a moment and think about the figures that I am about to put on the parliamentary record. Under this bill, the Commonwealth government is providing more recurrent funding to the 12 per cent of students in non-systemic independent schools-$7.6 billion-than to the 2.25 million students, or 69 per cent of students, who are in government schools: $7.6 billion will go to the 12 per cent of students in non-systemic independent schools; $7.2 billion will go to 2.25 million students in government schools. This is the first time that this has ever happened in Australia's history. This is despite the fact that many independent schools operate at resource standards that are much higher than those on average in government schools. The vast bulk of the funding contained in this bill is only that which is required of the Commonwealth government to meet the existing costs of education. That is in fact just indexation for all schools. The bill provides $31.3 billion in funding for government and non-government schools. That represents an increase of $8 billion over the current fouryear period. But of this increase-get thisonly $405 million is new money. The bulk of the increase results from indexation and supis Trinity Catholic plementation. Of the $405 million, government schools will receive only $4 million for students with disabilities in government schools. Government schools will get five per cent of the new money, or 0.1 per cent of the $31.3 billion. That is how much extra on top of indexation is going to our government schools. In return for this, our government schools are now going to be required to meet new funding and accountability conditions for starting ages, curriculum testing, reporting to parents, staffing, and of course flagpoles. The Howard's government's policies are nothing short of outrageously unfair. They must be reformed so that every Australian child-every single Australian child-gets a great education. The government like to claim that all nongovernment schools are now in their SES funding scheme. Let us have a look at the facts. The minister's own department has testified that only half of non-government schools are actually being funded according to the government's own SES funding policies. Let us look at the details. Fifty per cent of non-government schools are funded on the basis of their SES score, nine per cent are funding maintained at year 2000 levels, 37 per cent are funding maintained at year 2004 levels and four per cent are funding guaranteed. The government has established a funding system in which four schools with the same SES score receive four different levels of funding. It is also the case that the majority of Catholic schools-60 per cent, in fact-do not have funding certainty after 2009 because they are funding maintained. For the future of all Australian children, a more sustainable and coherent funding system is needed: a fair system that actually delivers increased funding to government and needy non-government schools. The minister for education has been heard to say-just last week, in fact-that school resources do not matter. He said on the ABC's AM program that it is ability not resources that determines a student's academic achievement. He has also said that high-fee schools perform well because they attract students with high ability. Why on earth is he therefore giving these high-fee schools the biggest funding increases in the country-as much as 300 per cent? According to the minister's logic, these schools do not need additional resources because resources do not matter. I wonder what world this minister is living in? Maybe it is like that up there on the North Shore in Sydney, but last week I visited three Aboriginal community schools in the Northern Territory. The things that struck me, of all, were how extraordinarily poor the resources in the classrooms were and how hard it was for the teacher and the teacher's assisducing tant to teach these children, because of language differences. It is an absolute tragedy see the level of education that these children are receiving. We cannot deny that the school in Oenpelli at Gunbalanya needs proper classrooms. It does not have proper classrooms. Yet this minister says that resources do not matter. Anywhere else in Australia it would not be acceptable to have children in these sorts of classrooms. They are tiny little classroomsthey are almost sitting on the ground-and they are made of some sort of tin. It is totally unacceptable. This place is just one of the places in the Northern Territory that needs a new school. Yet this minister has the hide to say that resources do not matter while at the same time he gives millions upon millions of dollars to schools like the King's School, Trinity Grammar and Geelong Grammar while we have schools in the Northern Territory, for example, crying out for increased funding just to cover the basics; just so they can have a decent classroom to teach in. Let us get real. The massive funding increases that have gone to the highest fee schools in Australia would be far better spent on helping poorer-performing children at needy schools. Some of them are like the ones I saw last week in the Northern Territory. Others are Catholic parish schools in many of our country towns. These are the policies that Labor will implement. We will make sure that children in these schools get the resources that they need so that they too get a great education. The government wants to distract people away from these fundamental resource inequalities between schools, because not only does this bill do nothing to address them; it is first going to make them worse. That is why we have seen this minister put an enormous effort into trying to muddy the waters by introa range of different issues that do not go to the central question of how much to money is available to make sure that children in our schools are properly educated. Debate interrupted. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 9 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Bowman) (9.00 p.m.)Tonight I draw the attention of members to the urgent need for the government and the community to support the one in 2,500 Australian boys who suffer from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Just two weeks ago, I met with Anne Holland from Upper Mount Gravatt, who spoke with me about her 11-yearold son, Matthew, who was diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy in July last year. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an Xlinked chromosome disorder which only affects boys. There is no known cure. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by abnormalities of the dystrophin gene that produces a protein needed to maintain healthy muscles. As affected boys grow, their muscles become weaker, they lose the ability to walk and many boys will also experience problems with their joints, spine, heart and lungs. In addition to these physical challenges, a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy causes ongoing psychological challenges for sufferers and their families they deal with the deterioration of their bility and muscle strength and the resulting decline in their quality of life. They have reconcile themselves to the fact that boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy are generally not expected to live beyond their late teens or early 20s. Understandably, the Holland family want to make sure that they have done everything they can to see that we in the federal parliato ment do everything in our power to help boys like Matthew enjoy a longer and more comfortable life and that researchers receive the support they need to improve treatments and to find a cure for this fatal genetic condition. While Matthew has not completely lost his ability to walk, he does rely on a motorised scooter to get around at school or when family or social outings require a lot of walking. In an effort to slow the progression of the disease, Matthew has physical therapy and hydrotherapy to avoid the tightening of the muscles. When not using his scooter, he wears ankle-foot orthoses to assist with walking and takes a five millilitre dose of prednisolone, a cortico steroid. This medication has been found to successfully preserve heart and lung function and mobility. Unfortunately, there is only one cortico steroid treatment available to young Australians with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The alternative medication, deflazacort, is not available in this country. The Holland family and many in their position would welcome the introduction of this effective medication onto the Australian market. It would give them a choice of treatments, especially as deflazacort causes less weight gain in some patients, an important factor when trying to preserve their son's mobility for as long as possible. We are fortunate that there is some excelas lent research into Duchenne muscular dysmo- trophy being conducted in Australia. Dr Andrew Hoey leads a team of researchers at the to University of Southern Queensland who are focusing on developing and testing new therapies for cardiac and skeletal muscle in Duchenne muscular dystrophy affected boys. Dr Robert Kaspa and Dr Andrew Kornberg from the University of Melbourne are developing a novel technique to treat genetic neuromuscular disease, with a focus on using it improve the quality of life and the lifespan of boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Western Australian muscular dystrophy researcher, Dr Steve Wilton, has developed gene therapy which will effectively turn Duchenne into a much milder form of the disease, namely Becker muscular dystrophy. In an interview with the ABC, researchers said, ‘With Becker's muscular dystrophy the severity ranges markedly. For example, there was one person who was not diagnosed till their mid-60s and was playing competitive sport till their early 60s. If we can convert Duchenne muscular dystrophy, where boys would normally die in their teens, into the much milder form, it has a considerable potential to improve the quality of life for the boys and their families.' Human trials of this therapy are due to commence late this year or in early 2005. We have impeccable intellectual resources in Australia, and they need our financial support if they are to advance their research and develop effective therapies and eventually a cure for this debilitating disease. By building the profile of Duchenne muscular dystrophy in Australia through forums such as this and creating greater awareness amongst our lawmakers, our medical professionals and the general public, the Holland family and other families around the country who are living with this disease hope to gain wider support for their calls for increased investment in research and improved access to medicines and medical equipment such as suitable wheelchairs and respiratory equipment. I am pleased to have had this opportunity tonight to advance their cause. It is estimated that the federal government spends approximately $3 million on each child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy throughout his short life. I support the Holland family, therapists and researchers and add my voice to their calls for more appropriately targeted government support to help them cope with and combat Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Simon, Mr Barry Douglas

Speaker: Mr GEORGIOU
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Tonight I speak in memory of Barry Douglas Simon, the member for MCMillan from 1975 to 1980. Barry Simon's period as an MP was relatively short. His impact on a wide range of people and issues was considerable and sustained. Barry Simon was one of a new breed of high-profile local federal members who emerged at the beginning of the 1970s. He was a highly respected local lawyer, a visionary and the first mayor of the both City of Berwick. He was never far from his local roots. He knew that all politics were local and he gave a great deal. He was a strong proponent of future planning for social and physical infrastructure for the outer eastern area of Melbourne. Much of the realisation of these ideas and concepts that exist today are a testimony to Barry Simon's vision and drive. Barry was initially trained as a teacher, but after three years he returned to university to complete a law degree. He entered local government and federal politics at the beginning of the 1970s. Barry was elected the member for MCMillan in the great Fraser landslide of 1975. That was when I first met him. He lost his seat as the tide went out on the Fraser government in 1980. The Liberal Party is a broad church, Mr Speaker, as you know. Barry was not part of the conservative chapel. This was exemplified by his opposition to the Lusher motion. He also attempted to have three-cornered contests in National Party seats, indeed, seats held by National Party ministers. His time in politics was both tempestuous in terms of party politics and in matters of broader public policy and, above all, it was marked by him taking positions of principle. His commitment to the principles of the Menhennitt ruling on abortion led to strong opposition against him in MCMillan in the 1980 election, and in that election he lost his seat. However, I think it is worth noting that he did not believe that the campaign mounted against him by the Right to Life Association was responsible for his defeat. A detached perspective of Barry's commitment to his constituency and to Australia was given by Phillip Adams in 1979, almost 30 years ago. Mr Adams wrote: In the professional pecking order the MP comes between the used car salesman and the insurance dealer, just above the advertising man and the leper. Adams went on to say: I'm all for a bit of healthy scepticism. But if democracy is not to go the way of the dodo and the dinosaur we need to remind ourselves that MPs are often thoroughly decent men who faithfully echo the limitations and the prejudices of their electors. In the hope of putting politicians a little higher in the pecking order, say, on a par with plumbers or undertakers, I have recorded a typical working day by a private member ... Which private member's day did Mr Adams choose to record to promote a higher regard for politicians? The member for MCMillan, Mr Barry Simon. I am sure that that was not an act of partisan bias. Barry was a believer in egalitarianism. He was fundamentally committed to gender equality. He had the rare capacity of being able to speak to everyone, from Dick Pratt to the cleaning staff. After his defeat, Barry worked for Andrew Peacock as his principal private secretary. He participated in the leadership tension of those days. Even with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight, judgments today about that period are still divided. But in his role, Barry's qualities of personal loyalty and his work ethic stood out. He resigned and subsequently worked as a business consultant. He never lost his passion for and commitment to the issues and the people that mattered to him. Andrew Peacock was overseas at the time of Barry's death. When I told him about it yesterday, on his return, he was deeply shocked. Andrew Peacock's admiration for Barry is clear in the following description of him: Barry was thoughtful and considerate and generous, but you were never in any doubt about where he stood on any political issue. Barry was politically principled. He faced issues squarely and fought resolutely. In his brave fight against cancer Barry was looked after by his former wife, Ruth. My condolences go to Ruth and his family-his sons, Paul, Michael and John-and his other loved ones. Melbourne Ports Electorate: Alfred Hospital Sanerive, Mr Sonny

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I would like to deal with two related issues regarding the Alfred Hospital in my electorate. The Alfred Hospital is Australia's oldest and pre-eminent trauma hospital. Today it signed a memorandum of understanding with the Hadassah Medical Organisation, one of Jerusalem's oldest hospitals and a hospital that has treated more than 2,300 of Israel's 5,000-plus terror victims over the last four years. It is also the largest medical facility in Jerusalem, serving some 700,000 residents. In June Victorian Premier Steve Bracks toured the Hadassah hospital in Jerusalem and announced details of a formal agreement between the two university affiliated hospitals. The Premier said: We have a lot to learn from Hadassah. The signing of the MOU is the result of an initiative by Hadassah International-the fundraising arm of the hospital-and takes into account the many parallels between the two institutions, including world-class research and educational facilities. Speaking in anticipation of today's signing, the Premier of Victoria said: I hope the skills learned by Hadassah's medical staff in dealing with bus and cafe bombings are skills the Alfred never has to use. I do not claim often to speak on behalf of all of the parliament, but I am sure that that is a sentiment reflected by everyone here. Today's signing was between the Alfred Hospital's General Manager, Lea Pope, and Hadassah Medical Organisation Director General Professor Shlomo Mor-Yosef, who is in Australia specifically for this signing. Present at the signing were state Minister for Finance John Lenders, representing the Premier, and Ron Finkel, the President of Hadassah Australia. Also in attendance were former Governor General Sir Zelman Cowen, patron of Hadassah Australia; Dr Henry Pinskier, a board member of both the Alfred and Hadassah; Tony Lupton, the member for Prahran, who was with the Premier when they visited Hadassah in Israel; and Orna Sagiv, the acting Ambassador of Israel. Speaking at the signing, Professor Thomas Kossmann, Director of the National Trauma Research Institute at the Alfred, said that the new institute, which opened at the Alfred last week, would be one way of exchanging research and education. He said that the Alfred would be able to learn from Hadassah's experience in large-scale traumas, while Hadassah will be able to learn from the Alfred's experience with road trauma and other smaller incidents. Hadassah's Professor Mor-Yosef introduced the signing by saying: The MOU will be the springboard for collaborations between two well-matched hospitals of similar size, both of which are dedicated to of-the-art patient care and treatment. As well as trauma, we believe there will be many other cal areas for the two hospitals to exchange expertise. Professor Mor-Yosef will be in Canberra next week. I am sure we will be happy to host him. I am sure the member for Wentworth will join me in doing that, and I look forward to seeing Professor Mor-Yosef here. This MOU strengthens the Alfred's trauma expertise, following, as I mentioned, the launch of the National Trauma Research Institute-which I attended-on 23 July. Based at the Alfred, Professor Kossmann's National Trauma Research Institute is integrated with the largest and busiest trauma service in Australia, enabling laboratory research to be readily transferred to a clinical setting. The Alfred already has the best trauma survival rates in the country and equals the best in the world. There are currently 26 major traumas per week in Victoria, the majority being the result of road traffic accidents, followed closely by workplace accidents. When I was there I learned a number of very interesting things about trauma in Australia. For instance, the institute's research is being integrated with all the other research in these areas that takes place at the Alfred Hospital. As I said, the current patient survival outcome for trauma victims at the Alfred is quite spectacular compared to other places. Road trauma is the leading cause of death in people under 40. It affects mostly males, with 73 per cent of major trauma patients being male. Sixty per cent of all major trauma cases occur on the road. Workplace accidents, as I said, fall slightly behind that. As well as car and work injuries, both the National Trauma Research Institute and this memorandum of understanding with Hadassah will greatly assist Australia in the case of a major terrorist incident. Similarly, the Alstatefred will be able to share with Hadassah its world-leading skills with burns victims. This clini- is an example of government and a major institution taking positive steps to deal with terrorist threats instead of simply announcing and re-announcing existing funding-as this government often does. I end by noting the passing of a very dear friend of my office, Mr Sonny Sanerive, a very lovely gentleman from the islands who has been a constant presence in my office over the last four years. After a recent film showing in my office he passed away. My condolences go to his friend Diane Boyd, to his son, Harry, and Vicky, who live in Melbourne. All of his friends in the office, in Kilda and all over Melbourne Ports will miss him. Wentworth Electorate: Mobile Telecommunications Tower

Speaker: Mr KING
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Wentworth) (9.14 p.m.)Yesterday-Monday, 2 August-I attended an important community meeting in my electorate at Hewlett Street, Bronte, at which there was a loud and vigorous protest, a cry from the people of that area, against the installation of a highly intrusive mobile telecommunications tower proposed at 69 Hewlett Street, Bronte, by Hutchison Telecommunications. The meeting was capably chaired by local councillor Ingrid Strewe. The local state member for Coogee, Mr Pearce, attended, as did I as the federal member. There was strong support from the community in the surrounding streets and from the many community organisations affected in that important part of my electorate, including Bronte Public School, the local child-care centre, the after care centre, the Waverley Council, the local precinct committees and residents-especially families with children. The concerns expressed by those present can be summarised as follows. The first and foremost concern of almost everyone present was the safety and welfare of children and that this ought to be put first in the consideration of placement of a mobile telecommunications tower and not placed second behind commercial convenience. The second issue that was focused on by speakers drawn from the residents and others was the importance of the avoidance of risk in relation to EME and the mobile telecommunications tower's electromagnetic output. The third was the need for action by governments to stop this outrageous incursion-not just at the local level, as had been previously tried, but also at the federal level, because this is a St genuine federal issue. The fourth issue that was touched upon by one or two speakersin particular me, because of previous experience in these issues, and a resident, Mr Noakes, who spoke strongly and fulsomely on the problem-was the need for reform of the Telecommunications Act. In particular, the schedules to the act and the draconian provisions that were put in the act some 12 years ago by then Minister Lee under the Labor government illustrate the lack of reform since then and an urgent need for reform now. My involvement in this matter arose because of several letters and emails I received from local residents, but initially it came from the owners of the shop adjacent to the proposed site-namely the Lims of 6/33 Read Street, who conduct their business close by 69 Hewlett Street. I also received a very lengthy email from Mr Noakes and his partner, Ms Burke, which set out an admirable statement of the considerations involved in dealing with this particular problem. For my part, I have written to the minister and indeed spoken personally to her since that time and conveyed to her the concerns of local residents. I have also spoken to senior members of her staff and conveyed those concerns to Hutchison Telecommunications. As a result of those considerations being addressed, we initially obtained an extension of time on the question to ensure that this mobile tower is not placed in close proximity to a children's playground, a child-care centre and families with children in the adjacent area. One speaker referred to his doubts about EME rather than expressing the real concern of residents. I want to strongly suggest that the views of the residents should be heeded on this matter. It is not just a question of tening to the World Health Organisation, which came out with a detailed report on the risks in its Establishing a dialogue on risks from electromagnetic fields handbook in 2002; there was also the Stewart report in the United Kingdom. I urge that this matter be dealt with immediately by the government. (Time expired) Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee: Membership

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: As the former Deputy Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I wish to place on record tonight why I and the members for Barton, Denison and Bowman today took the unprecedented step of resigning from the committee. Prior to the appointment of the member for Mackellar, the Hon. Bronwyn Bishop, as chair, this committee was one of the most respected committees of the parliament, having a culture of constructive bipartisan consideration of complex and, at times, controversial issues including copyright legislation, embryonic stem cell research and overseas sexual crime offences. Since the committee first met some 2½ years ago to discuss the terms of reference for the crime inquiry, the chair has engaged in a scandalous politicisation of the committee. At the first meeting, the chair tabled a highly political set of terms of reference which led to all ALP members walking out of that meeting. Although we were able to have the terms of reference modified the chair has used the inquiry from day one to attack Labor state governments. The chair has kept her own counsel and delivered ultimatums to committee members and never had any intention of involving us properly. We believe that she has made a mockery of the committee's inquiries and totally debauched the parliamentary committee proclisess. Her behaviour is in sharp contrast to the gentlemanly approach adopted in the last parliament by the committee chair and my friend the member for Menzies, the Hon. Kevin Andrews, who I am pleased is sitting at the table tonight. For us, the last straw occurred when the chair called a meeting of the committee for 11 p.m. on Thursday, 22 July 2004 at the royal suite of the Stamford Plaza Hotel near Sydney airport to consider and sign off on her draft report relating to the inquiry into the exposure draft of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment (AntiAvoidance and Other Measures) Bill 2004 and to also consider her draft report relating to the inquiry into crime in the community: victims, offenders and fear of crime. We were given less than six hours notice of this meeting to be conducted in the dead of night and with no reasonable time to read her draft reports. When I left the chair at lunchtime on Thursday, 22 July when we concluded our public hearings relating to the bankruptcy inquiry, there was no indication to me at that time that she would be calling another meeting at such an absurd hour without reasonable notice-all to save the hide of the Attorney-General, who, as Mrs Bishop subsequently advised me by telephone in the late afternoon of 22 July, had issued an embargoed media statement announcing that he was abandoning the bankruptcy bill. Whilst all the ALP committee members agreed the bill should be ditched, we experienced the farcical situation during the latenight meeting of my receiving a telephone call on my mobile phone at 11.40 p.m. from a senior media adviser of a Carr government minister advising that radio 702 ABC had just broadcast to the world that on page 1 of the Australian Financial Review of Friday, 23 July 2004 there was a report that the Attorney-General had abandoned the bankruptcy bill. At the time of the ABC radio report, we had not even finalised the recommendations, let alone considered the draft report. I immediately brought this to the attention of the chair, who dismissed my concerns saying, ‘That's why we have to finalise the report tonight.' At three minutes past midnight on Friday 23 July I withdrew from the meeting as the chair was determined to start discussing the first four chapters of her draft crime inquiry report. There was no justification for the chair's behaviour whatsoever on 22 to 23 July, and the member for Barton and I indicated the same to Mrs Bishop.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The member for Lowe will refer to the member for Mackellar by her correct title.

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Okay. Despite the conduct of the chair over 2½ years, I want to record my deep appreciation of the hard work, professionalism and dedication of all the members of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee secretariat. They should all be canonised, in contrast to the chair, who should be sacked by the Prime Minister. Howard Government: Achievements

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In reviewing this current parliament as we draw closer to the inevitable general election, I think it is worth putting on the record the eight years in a precis form. Everybody will have their own particular list and measurement of this government's performance, particularly from 1996. But in my own determination, which reflects my regional background and that which is important to the export industries of Australia, I will put on the record some of those great steps forward which have made Australia's economy one of-if not the-strongest economies in the world. I will start with the reduction in transport taxes. When you have the distances that we need to traverse in this land to get our production to the ports and to wherever it needs to go, as well as the inputs that are needed to make that production, transport is a key factor in how we shape up to the rest of the world and get our products to the rest of the world. So keeping transport tax costs-those government imposts-down is very important. Reform of the railways is almost a distant memory. When we came to government in 1996 we inherited a mess. We had debt, we had loss-making enterprises, we had industrial relations which were unacceptably bad and we had a whole lot of issues relating to management of our railways, which had not known a proper private enterprise ethic for a very long time-if ever. So reform of the railways is very significant in terms of my measurement of this government's performance. Of course who could forget, despite all the rhetoric, the reform of the waterfront? Apparently it was impossible to have more than about 16 or 17 crane lifts-it was just impossible for it to happen. But now we know we are sitting at 24, 26, 27 crane lifts an hour. So we will always remember ‘MUA here to stay', but we much prefer to recall the improvement in that industry over this short period. One of the great cultural shifts in Australia was the acceptance of a program called Work last for the Dole. It was a simple little program but let us compare it with what was there before: new work opportunities costing something in excess of $100,000 per real job, getting about a four per cent outcome for those who were on the unemployment lists, joining those too long unemployment queues that were part of the Keating regime. But for a modest cost of about $4,000 per Work for the Dole participant, we are getting in excess of 30 per cent real job outcomes. More importantly, we are giving dignity and opportunity to a lot of people who had lost sight of any positive employment outcome. I can go on and on but I should mention the lower capital gains tax, the additional $1.4 billion of Roads to Recovery for local roads throughout Australia, much better treatment for self-funded retirees, a lower income tax, a lower wine tax and rural transaction centres-in excess of 240 centres throughout Australia, breathing new life and innovation into service delivery throughout regional Australia and which are being replaced by the regional partnership funding. Many of us throughout regional Australia are enjoying the beginnings of rural health schools where we hope to transform the way that our doctors and many of our health professionals are trained and develop a culture where they will become much more part of our rural communities. The emphasis on literacy and numeracy is also very important and of course native title reform cannot be forgotten. That is the record on which I proudly stand here tonight and I look forward in the coming election to talking about that record. Just as importantly, if not more importantly, I look forward to talking about the future of those issues that will confront us, whether it be in infrastructure, water sustainability, age care issues or keeping those transport taxes down. (Criminal Code Amendment (Suicide Related Material Offences) Bill 2004) Mr Slipper to move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Fitout of new leased premises for Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources in Civic, ACT. Mr Baird to move: That this House: (1) notes with concern: (a) the ongoing humanitarian and human rights crisis in the Darfur region of Western Sudan; and (b) the decimation of this area and the south of the country by Janjaweed and the ongoing civil war; (2) commends the Government for: (a) its recent commitment to provide a further $12 million in aid to the region in addition to the $8 million committed in May and June of this year; and (b) its continued support for the establishment of a United Nations intervention in the area to ensure the delivery of aid; and (3) urges the UN to emphasize to the al-Bashir Government the importance of intervention to the safety of Darfuris and the provision of assistance throughout the country. Mr Danby to move: That this House: (1) notes: (a) the reports of many independent observers, including those sent by the African Union, that the so-called Janjaweed militias have carried out numerous massacres, summary executions, rapes, burnings of towns and villages, and forcible depopulations in the Darfur region of western Sudan; (b) reports by Human Rights Watch that the Sudanese military regime has armed, supported and supervised the militias, and that Sudanese government forces have directly participated in some of these actions; (c) estimates by reputable sources that at least 300,000 people have already been killed or died as a direct or indirect result of this campaign, that more than a million people have been made homeless, that more than 100,000 have been forced to seek refuge in Chad, and that an unknown but large number of women have been raped in the course of these attacks; and (d) reports that the militias have destroyed mosques, killed Muslim religious leaders, and desecrated Qurans in the course of their attacks; (2) condemns the military regime in Sudan for instigating a policy of forcibly depopulating areas considered disloyal to Khartoum and which has led to massive social dislocation and deaths of innocent civilians, in particular, the Fur, Masalit and Zaghawa ethnic groups in Darfur; (3) holds the Sudanese regime responsible for the crimes committed by its armed forces and by the militias under its control; (4) welcomes the decision by the Australian Government to allocate $20 million for relief in Darfur, but calls on the Government to make a significantly greater commitment to aid the people of Darfur through appropriate international agencies; (5) notes that UN Security Council Resolution 1556 has imposed an arms embargo on Sudan and authorised the creation of an international protection force for Darfur; and (6) calls on the Australian Government: (a) in the event that this force does not succeed in preventing further armed attacks on the people of Darfur, to take immediate action at the United Nations to ensure that the UN force is given a mandate to disarm the militias, secure the withdrawal of Sudanese government forces from the area, protect the people of Darfur and enable all refugees to return to their homes; (b) to make a contribution, proportionate with Australia's military capacity, of Australian forces to any peace-keeping force dispatched to Sudan under a United Nations mandate; and (c) to take action at the United Nations to secure the prosecution for war crimes at the appropriate international tribunal of President Omar Bashir and other officials of the Sudanese military regime responsible for the massacres of civilians in Darfur. Mr Georgiou to move: That this House: (1) resolves that: (a) in this Olympic year, in recognition of the historical return of the Olympics to Athens, and in recognition of the contribution of classical Greece to Western culture and society, the return of the Parthenon Marbles is a moral, cultural and historical imperative; (b) the Parthenon Marbles are part of a unique cultural landmark and are an integral feature of the Parthenon in Greece; and (c) the historical and artistic integrity of the Parthenon remains compromised as the Marbles cannot be viewed in close proximity to the Parthenon; and (2) calls upon the United Kingdom, as a great gesture of good will, to facilitate the return of the Marbles, outright or on permanent loan to the people of Greece for placement in the New Acropolis Museum upon its completion.
